page.title: 01An Overview of The Block
page.content: In the northeast corner of the block is the village of Colwall(pop. c.2000) and most of the remaining area is farmland, with crop growing the main activity.The most significant feature is the Malvern Hills which provide a magnificent backdrop for the area.The soil is largely composed of clay. The most famous village resident was probably the poet William Langland, a contempory of Chaucer, and when he sat on the hills and wrote about 'a fair field full of folk' he was referring to his native village. Colwall's name is probably derived from 'cool well'. The village contains the only two industries of this block -the bottling of Malvern Water - and a plastics factory.The village occupants consist largely of those who commute to the cities of Worcester,Birmingham, and Coventry, and many retired people.
